title: Question 118

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated because of an ulcer between his toes. The ulcer is painful and is worse with leg elevation. He has peripheral artery disease.

Physical examination shows an ulcer involving the medial aspects of the third and fourth digits. It has well-demarcated borders with a dry and "punched-out" appearance. The ulcer base is pale pink in color. There is no bleeding.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Arterial ulcers occur in the setting of significant peripheral vascular disease, usually at the distal aspects of the arterial supply (such as the distal toes) or in areas of trauma (such as overlying the metatarsal heads or shins and ankles).
Venous stasis ulcers account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers, occurring most commonly near the medial malleolus, and are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency.

). Arterial ulcers occur in the setting of significant peripheral vascular disease and result from inadequate perfusion of the lower extremities. Ulceration usually occurs at the distal aspects of the arterial supply (such as the distal toes) or in areas of trauma (such as overlying the metatarsal heads or shins and ankles). The ulcers are usually tender, have a well-demarcated border with a “punched-out” appearance, and are surrounded by erythematous, tight skin. Leg elevation often results in worsening pain, and examination may reveal diminished or absent peripheral pulses.

The initial presentation may start as tender, dusky red macules or a livedo reticularis pattern. It quickly progresses to tender subcutaneous plaques with an overlying dusky red discoloration. Surrounding purpura is often found. The area of involvement quickly expands in an angulated arrangement. As the skin infarcts, a black eschar forms. This patient's findings are not compatible with calciphylaxis.

Diabetic ulcers are painless, are most common on the plantar surface of the feet, and have associated callus and foot deformity. Examination typically shows diminished sensation.

Venous stasis ulcers can be single or multiple and are typically irregularly shaped, shallow, and often weep serous fluid. Physical findings suggestive of venous stasis ulcers include edema, varicosities, eczematous changes, brown pigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, atrophie blanche, and evidence of healed ulcers.
